title: Taking Control of Your CML in the Doctor's Office

content: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) could be with you for many years, and it can be serious. A good relationship with your medical team will help you get on the treatment to control your cancer and feel your best. Evidence suggests you may get better results when you advocate for yourself. Self-advocacy is when you take control of your own care, stand up for your rights, and make sure your needs are met. These steps will help you take a more active role in your treatment.

sections.heading: Get to Know Your Cancer
content: The first step in taking control of your CML is to learn everything you can about it. You'll be a better advocate for yourself and will feel more confident talking with your doctor if you understand the condition. Read about CML and your treatment options from credible sources. Start with your doctor. When you take to the internet, be careful not to fall down the rabbit hole of false information on social media. Instead, search credible sources like these cancer organizations: American Cancer Society (ACS). This nonprofit organization works to improve the lives of people with cancer. The ACS website has information about leukemia and support programs for people with cancer. Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS). LLS is the largest nonprofit organization dedicated to blood cancers. It sponsors research and offers free education and support for people with leukemia and lymphoma. National Cancer Institute (NCI). NCI is the U.S. government's agency for cancer research. Its mission is to help people with all types of cancer live longer and better lives. If the amount of information you find feels too overwhelming, ask a friend or family member you trust to help you sort through it.

sections.heading: Be Prepared
content: You have a limited amount of time to spend with your doctor at each visit. You'll get more out of these visits if you arrive prepared. Keep track of any new symptoms you've had since your last appointment. Write down when they started and how severe they are. Bring a list of all the medications you take. Include over-the-counter drugs, vitamins , and supplements. Note the doses, too.

content: Write a list of your questions. Put the most important questions first in case you don't have time to cover all of them during the visit. You might ask: What do my test results mean? Why do you recommend this treatment? How might the treatment help me? What side effects could it cause? What other treatment options do I have? Can I take part in a clinical trial? When should I start to see improvements? What are the odds I'll go into remission ? What can I do at home to manage symptoms and treatment side effects?

content: Be ready to discuss any concerns you've had, like mood changes or medication side effects. Take notes in a notebook or on your phone. Or bring a friend or family member with you to take notes so you can focus on the conversation with your doctor. After you get home, read through your notes. Call or email your doctor's office if you don't understand something or you have more questions.

sections.heading: Speak Up About Your Needs and Concerns
content: Good communication with your treatment team is an important part of self-advocacy. Tell your doctor what you want and need, ask questions when you don't understand something, and be open about any concerns you have. You may not always agree with your treatment team. That's OK. But you should feel comfortable telling them how you feel. If you aren't confident enough to speak up for yourself, ask whether your cancer hospital has a patient advocate who can speak for you.

sections.heading: Build a Support Network
content: Learning from other people with CML can make you a better self-advocate. You can meet them in a support group at your cancer hospital or online through an organization like the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. Research suggests that people with cancer gain strength from support groups.

sections.heading: Know Your Rights
content: You are a member of your treatment team. As a teammate, you have rights. You have the right to a second opinion. Leukemia is a complex cancer to treat. Talking to another doctor can make you feel more confident that you've chosen the right treatment. You can find another cancer doctor through your health insurance company or local hospital.

sections.heading: You have the right to say no to a treatment.
content: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are the standard treatment for chronic phase CML. But these targeted drugs might not be right for you, or they could cause side effects that you can't tolerate. Your needs and lifestyle should also be a part of treatment decisions. You can say no or ask about your other options. You have the right to be comfortable during treatment. Nausea, diarrhea, cramps, and bone pain are common side effects of TKIs. Other CML treatments come with their own side effects. Tell your doctor about any problems you have during treatment. Medicines or changes to your personal habits can prevent or manage many CML treatment side effects.

sections.heading: Find Out What's Next
content: You may need to be on CML treatment for the rest of your life. Ask your doctor what to expect in the future: How often will you monitor my response to treatment? What tests will you do at each visit? What are the chances that my cancer will go into remission? What happens if it comes back after remission? What is my long-term outlook? What symptoms should I call you about between appointments? Learning how to advocate for yourself takes time and practice. Through some trial and error, you can learn how to speak up for yourself and communicate better with your treatment team. Taking an active role in your treatment will make you feel empowered and give you more control over your own future.
